title: Boys Shot Put Distances: Percentile from a Histogram
question_text:
The histogram below shows results for the $23\text{ boys}$ who competed in the shot put event at a state track and field meet.

Of the following, which is the best estimate of the distance needed (in meters) to be at the $75^\text{th}\text{ percentile}$?
solution:
The
75
th
 percentile
is the value that is greater than or equal to
75
%
of the observations. Since there are
23
observations, we need to determine what number is
75
%
of
23
. This can be done as follows:

(
0.75
)
(
23
)
=
17.25

This means that when listed in order from smallest to largest, the
18
th
observation is the value that is at the
75
th
 percentile
. It is the value that we know will be greater than or equal to
75
%
of the observations.

To find this value, match the height of each bar to the corresponding frequency of observations. Keep track of the cumulative frequency until you reach the
18
th
largest observation.

This tells us that the
18
th
largest observation is somewhere between
15
and
16
 meters
.

Choice 'B' is the correct choice because it is the only value provided which falls between
15
and
16
 meters
.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect. This would be a reasonable estimate for the center of the distribution, or the
50
th
 percentile
.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. This would be a reasonable estimate for the
19
th
 observation
when listed from smallest to largest.

Choice 'D' is incorrect. This value represents
75
%
of
23
but does not correspond with the
75
th
 percentile
.

Choice 'E' is incorrect. This might be a reasonable estimate for the maximum distance.
